As actions are monitored by working groups, various bodies and institutions to carry out studies and legal-normative diagnoses and composition of databases, preparation of proposals, survey of needs and promotion of information technology solutions, search for efficiency in the generation of statistics and holding events aimed at the evolution of themes through debates. Actions for the year 2019 included the development of a digital platform project and other measures of public transparency, public data and social participation (7). First, the data is processed to find inconsistencies and duplications. A quality report is sent to states and municipalities to guide managers in organizing the database. The Departments start the survey only in the month of March, within 60 (sixty) days after the end of the month in which the death occurred. Data are reviewed and processed by the Ministries of Health. Data processing is based on administrative rule 116 of 2009 (7).

There is the Federal Executive's Open Data Policy, which defines rules and resources for making open government data available. The initiative was built on a series of documents, regulations, and standards. In a broader context, the initiative is influenced by the partnership with the Open Government Partnership (1) and the National Action Plans (currently the 4th Plan), and by the institution of a legal framework related to open data, digital government strategies, data governance, and interoperability: Access to Information Act, National Open Data Infrastructure, Open Data Policy, National Information Security Policy, General Personal Data Protection Act, and other related legislation (2).
The Federal Comptroller General (CGU) is the main body responsible for managing and overseeing the Policy - decree 9903 of 2019 (3), through the National Open Data Infrastructure (INDA) (4). A multi-stakeholder Management Committee supports INDA (5). The main resource for organizing the data is the Brazilian Open Data Portal (6), which works as a search and use catalog of data published by government agencies.
The planning of actions to implement and promote the opening of data by agencies is operationalized by the Open Data Plan (7). To execute the plan, there is an Open Data Plan Preparation Manual (8). The Federal Comptroller General created the Open Data Policy Monitoring Panel (9), which allows the population to verify whether the administrative bodies are complying with the legal provisions and compliance with the respective plan.
The execution of the Open Data Plans has a data availability schedule. However, there is a limitation of resources between public administration bodies and entities (10), according to initial information on the Portal.
The Portal is the reference for searching and accessing public data, its metadata, information, applications. Each agency should catalog data on the portal, following the guidelines of the Cataloging Manual (11) and the Open Data Kit (12), which is a set of tools and guidance documents for the implementation of the Open Data Policy.
Despite the robustness of the Policy (13), which consists of a commitment to openness (1), a data infrastructure (4), with a portal (6) and guidance documents (12), implementation resources (8), and follow-up the adoption of open data from public bodies (9), the role of the Comptroller General of the Union is not clear. It is not possible to obtain information on the initiative's maintenance budget (14), as the IT Spending Panel is under maintenance. Finally, there is no clarity about the role of the INDA Management Committee (http://wiki.dados.gov.br/Comite-Gestor-da-INDA.ashx), whose last stock balance update is in December 2018 (15 ) This negatively affects the government's commitment to transparency, one of the pillars of the partnership with the Open Government Partnership, a recurring theme in public consultations for the preparation of Action Plans (16).

indicators.justification:
Brazil offers a comprehensive framework for protecting personal data. Since 2010 the legal framework for the protection of personal data has been developed in the country (1). The chronology is as follows: in 2013 a bill was proposed on the processing and use of personal data in the Federal Senate; in 2015 the project proposal was approved; in 2017, other projects began to be processed in the Chamber and Senate; the General Personal Data Protection Law was enacted in August 2018; in 2019, the creation of the National Data Protection Authority was approved; the general protection law entered into force in August 2020 (2).

Law no. 13.709, of August 14, 2018, General Law for the Protection of Personal Data provides citizens with control over the treatment of their data, through principles and rules that must be observed by private and public organizations.

The main foundations (3) of the law respect for, informative self-determination, freedom of expression, information, communication, and opinion; inviolability of intimacy, honor, and image; economic and technological development and innovation; free enterprise, free competition, and consumer protection; human rights, the free development of personality, dignity and the exercise of citizenship by natural persons.

The law provides under which circumstances the processing of data can be carried out, distinguishes personal data from sensitive data, determines the rights of the data subject regarding the processing, collection, and control; establishes the principles of data processing by the government; creates two people to control, operate and respond to data processing, the person in charge and the controller (3).

The general law was modified to create compliance guidelines and the oversight body. Law no. 13,853, of July 8, 2019 (4) established measures to ensure compliance with data protection rules, created the National Data Protection Authority, a body linked to the Presidency of the Republic, and the National Council for the Protection of Personal Data and Privacy.
The authority is responsible for drafting the guidelines for the National Policy for the Protection of Personal Data and Privacy; monitor and apply sanctions in case of non-compliance with the law or irregularities. The authority must promote knowledge of the norms for the population, safety and security policies, and cooperate with authorities in other countries.

The National Council for the Protection of Personal Data and Privacy acts as a consultation body for the national authority, proposing guidelines, providing subsidies for the creation of national policy, preparation of studies, debates, and public hearings (4). The Council is composed of members of civil society and public authorities, who were recently selected through a public notice (5).

Since the beginning of the Covid-19 Pandemic, Open Knowledge Brasil has pointed out the urgent need for data on all government measures related to the fight against the corona virus. In partnership with other organizations,Transparency Brazil, Transparency
International – Brazil, Covid-19 BR Observatory, Solidarity Research Network in Public Policy and Society and Brazilian Association of Investigative Journalism , Abraji, Purpose and Lagom data's Anti-Corruption Laboratory, launched the covid-19 transparency index that assesses the content, granularity and form of data and information related to the pandemic of the new coronavirus that have been published by the Union, states and Brazilian capitals in their official portals (1).
The collection of data evaluated by the Index is based on the latest periodical publications from official portals of the health and control agencies of municipal, state and federal governments. Since March 2020, when the Ministry of Health stopped publishing municipal data, case histories and deaths from Covid-19, the community and its creators began to collect data from the Health Departments. The study by the Administrative Council for Economic Defense (1) and the Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development to examine the existing federal public procurement regime in Brazil, indicated advances in contract planning since 2019. However, it recommended the creation of specialized sectors in market analysis, expansion and strengthening of hiring via electronic systems in preference to face-to-face systems (1) (2).
By constitutional attribution, the Courts of Auditors carry out the inspection of public contracts and the expenses made based on the bidding law (art. 113) (3). The Court carried out an operational audit with the objective of evaluating the Annual Contracting Plan (PAC) and the Contracting Planning and Management System (PGC) (4). The audit in the system and in the database pointed out: typing errors, system weaknesses, system database that presents inconsistencies, there is a need to carry out a 'cleaning' of the data. In addition, the rapporteur pointed out that "Although the system data serve to subsidize joint purchases by the Purchasing Center, which already allows for economy and administrative rationality for the government, the potential resulting from the more effective use of the system can be much greater ( 5)".
The Court of Auditors recommended to the Ministry of Economy's Management Secretariat an action plan to correct the system's problems, addressing "usability weaknesses", "completion difficulties", "frequent registration, password and profile expiration", "lack integration with other public contracting regimes, "extensive forms" and "lack of integrity", among others, as well as the adoption of measures to improve the maturity of bodies in the preparation of annual plans (5).
